Name: Palmitic acid
Description: Hexadecanoic acid is a straight-chain, sixteen-carbon, saturated long-chain fatty acid. It has a role as an EC 1.1.1.189 (prostaglandin-E2 9-reductase) inhibitor, a plant metabolite, a Daphnia magna metabolite and an algal metabolite. It is a long-chain fatty acid and a straight-chain saturated fatty acid. It is a conjugate acid of a hexadecanoate.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Chung TY et al; J Agric Food Chem 41: 1693-97 (1993) (2) Taira H et al; J Agric Food Chem 36: 45-47 (1988) (3) Takeoka GR et al; J Agric Food Chem 36: 553-60 (1988) (4) Guadayol JM et al; J Agric Food Chem 45: 1868-72 (1997) (5) Rogge WF et al; Environ Sci Technol 27: 2700-11 (1993) (6) Kim Y-S, Shin D-H; J Agric Food Chem 52: 781-787 (2004)
plant_concentrations.Value: Palmitic acid was identified as a volatile constituent of the Korean chamchwi plant (Aster scaber Thunb), concentration less than 0.02 % of total sample(1). Mature grains of 15 nonglutinous cultivars each of Indica, Sinica, Javanica, and Japonica brown rice collected in Japan and China in 1984 were determined to have an average of 19.56, 18.33, 15.20, and 16.79 % palmitic acid content, respectively(2). Palmitic acid has been identified as a volatile constituent of nectarine(3). Palmitic acid was found in paprika oleoresin at <0.1 mg/kg(4). Palmitic acid was found in fine particulate abrasion products from green leaves at a concentration of 835.4 ug/g and from dead leaves at a concentration of 589.9 ug/g; samples collected were from trees characteristic of the Los  Angeles, CA area(5). Palmitic acid was identified as a volatile constituent of Callicarpa japonica Thunb. leaves collected from Jeonju, Korea in September 2001(6).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Burdock GA, ed; Fenaroli's Handbook of Flavor Ingredients. 6th ed., Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press p. 1584-1585 (2010) (2) Hesselberg RJ, Seelye JG; Identification of Organic Compounds in Great Lakes Fishes by Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectrometry: 1977. Admen Rep No 82-1. Ann Arbor, MI: US Fish Wildlife Soc Great Lakes Fishery Lab (1982) (3) Avery EL et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 35: 229-35 (1998)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Palmitic acid is reported, not quantified, in fatty fish, shrimp, crab, clam, and scallop(1). Palmitic acid was found in samples of adult lake trout (Salvelinus namaycush) and walleye (Stizostedion v. vitreum) that were collected in 1977 from each of the Great Lakes and Lake St. Clair, quantity unknown(2). Palmitic acid was detected in Sydney rock oysters (Saccostrea commercialis) from the Hunter region of New South Wales, Australia; of 83 controls palmitic acid was found at 53.113% of lipid material and of 59 samples taken in sewage polluted water stearic acid was found at 50.414% of lipid material(3).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Muszkat L et al; Arch Insect Biochem Physiol 22: 487-99 (1993) (2) Rushdi AI et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 49: 457-470 (2005)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Palmitic acid was identified 20 meters deep in an effluent irrigated citrus grove in Israel at a concentration of 15 ppb(1). During winter 2002 soil and sand samples, from six locations in the Riyadh metropolitan area of Saudi Arabia, were examined for extractable organic matter; palmitic acid was detected at each location with relative concentrations of 0.06 to 3.25% (of total extractable organic matter)(2).
